title: Add add_smoothed_particle_field

content.raw:
Can you add a test for this? You can likely follow the tests I created for `add_deposited_particle_field`.

If you feel ambitious, it would also be good to add docs for both of these functions somewhere in the documentation. It looks like they only show up in the API docs right now.
content.html:
Can you add a test for this? You can likely follow the tests I created for add_deposited_particle_field.

If you feel ambitious, it would also be good to add docs for both of these functions somewhere in the documentation. It looks like they only show up in the API docs right now.

content.raw: Okay, I'll try to do those things.
content.html: Okay, I'll try to do those things.

content.raw: On this line and two lines above "deposited" should probably be  "smoothed"
content.html: On this line and two lines above "deposited" should probably be "smoothed"

content.raw: Can only be
content.html: Can only be

content.raw: Since this defaults to `None` maybe you should note how many neighbors are used by default? Alternatively it could default to some reasonable integer.
content.html: Since this defaults to None maybe you should note how many neighbors are used by default? Alternatively it could default to some reasonable integer.

content.raw: Can you raise this error with an explanatory message? Something like `raise RuntimeError("smooth_field must be a tuple, received %s" % smooth_field )`. Same with the `NotImplementedError` below.
content.html: Can you raise this error with an explanatory message? Something like raise RuntimeError("smooth_field must be a tuple, received %s" % smooth_field ). Same with the NotImplementedError below.

content.raw: We have a bunch of custom exceptions defined in `yt/utilities/exceptions.py` if you want to get some ideas from there.  Feel free to add new ones as appropriate.
content.html: We have a bunch of custom exceptions defined in yt/utilities/exceptions.py if you want to get some ideas from there. Feel free to add new ones as appropriate.

content.raw: It default to ``None`` because in ``add_volume_weighted_smoothed_field`` the default is ``None``. But I don't understand why it's so. In other places I think the default is ``64``. In ``OctreeSubset.smooth`` for example. Should I change the default to ``64``?
content.html: It default to None because in add_volume_weighted_smoothed_field the default is None. But I don't understand why it's so. In other places I think the default is 64. In OctreeSubset.smooth for example. Should I change the default to 64?

content.raw: 64 is reasonable.
content.html: 64 is reasonable.

content.raw: I just found that ``nneighbors`` is not passed to ``data.smooth`` in ``add_volume_weighted_smoothed_field``!
content.html: I just found that nneighbors is not passed to data.smooth in add_volume_weighted_smoothed_field!

content.raw: Sounds like a bug! Is it set to 64 at a lower level?
content.html: Sounds like a bug! Is it set to 64 at a lower level?

content.raw:
This is a bit nitpicky but it's important for readability - the function definition here isn't formatted right.  I would format it like this:

```
#!python

    def add_smoothed_particle_field(self, smooth_field, method="volume_weighted",
                                    nneighbors=None, kernel_name="cubic"):
```

The most important bit is that the arguments inside the parenthesis are vertically aligned, like `self` and `nneighbors` in my example.
content.html:
This is a bit nitpicky but it's important for readability - the function definition here isn't formatted right. I would format it like this:

    def add_smoothed_particle_field(self, smooth_field, method="volume_weighted",
                                    nneighbors=None, kernel_name="cubic"):

The most important bit is that the arguments inside the parenthesis are vertically aligned, like self and nneighbors in my example.

content.raw: In ``data.smooth``, which I think could only be ``OctreeSubset.smooth``, it defaults to 64.
content.html: In data.smooth, which I think could only be OctreeSubset.smooth, it defaults to 64.

content.raw: I think you should probably raise an error if `(ptype, smoothing_length_name) not in self.derived_field_list` is `True`.
content.html: I think you should probably raise an error if (ptype, smoothing_length_name) not in self.derived_field_list is True.

content.raw: So it does not matter if one line is a little longer than 80, right?
content.html: So it does not matter if one line is a little longer than 80, right?

content.raw: Thank you for all your suggestions! I'll work on them for a while.
content.html: Thank you for all your suggestions! I'll work on them for a while.

content.raw:
It comes out to 77 characters the way I have it above :)

Going a bit over 80 characters is fine although I don't normally feel like I need to . If you find yourself writing a long function name and don't have a lot of room for the argument list, it's also OK with respect to pep 8 if you do this:


```
#!python

def add_smoothed_particle_field(
            self, smooth_field, method="volume_weighted", nneighbors=None,
            kernel_name="cubic")
```
content.html:
It comes out to 77 characters the way I have it above :)

Going a bit over 80 characters is fine although I don't normally feel like I need to . If you find yourself writing a long function name and don't have a lot of room for the argument list, it's also OK with respect to pep 8 if you do this:

def add_smoothed_particle_field(
            self, smooth_field, method="volume_weighted", nneighbors=None,
            kernel_name="cubic")

content.raw:
This is a lot easier to set up now: http://i.imgur.com/Vov9qc0.png

Once my nits below are satisfied and there are tests I think this would be a great addition.
content.html:
This is a lot easier to set up now: http://i.imgur.com/Vov9qc0.png

Once my nits below are satisfied and there are tests I think this would be a great addition.

content.raw: Maybe I should just remove the parameter ``nneighbors``? Since it will be set to 64 at lower level anyway.
content.html: Maybe I should just remove the parameter nneighbors? Since it will be set to 64 at lower level anyway.

content.raw: I think @MatthewTurk intended it to be configurable. Can't we just pass it down to the lower level?
content.html: I think Matt Turk intended it to be configurable. Can't we just pass it down to the lower level?

content.raw: Sure. So should the default value be ``None`` or ``64``?
content.html: Sure. So should the default value be None or 64?

content.raw: Since it's supposed to be an integer 64 is probably clearer
content.html: Since it's supposed to be an integer 64 is probably clearer

content.raw: I agree!
content.html: I agree!

content.raw: Then I should write in the docstring it's useless to change the parameter here for now, right?
content.html: Then I should write in the docstring it's useless to change the parameter here for now, right?

content.raw: I would just make it possible to set the neighbor count as part of this pull request. Of course if that turns out to be harder than you want to deal with right now you could disable the ability to change it here.
content.html: I would just make it possible to set the neighbor count as part of this pull request. Of course if that turns out to be harder than you want to deal with right now you could disable the ability to change it here.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: I have made a mistake in this commit. What is the preferred way to fix it?
content.html: I have made a mistake in this commit. What is the preferred way to fix it?

content.raw: Push a new commit that fixes the issue.
content.html: Push a new commit that fixes the issue.

content.raw: ok
content.html: ok

content.raw:
I think you're going to need to create a fake particle dataset. You'll also need to add a smoothing field.

Right now this fails with:


```
#!
E
======================================================================
ERROR: yt.fields.tests.test_fields.test_add_smoothed_particle_field
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/case.py", line 197, in runTest
    self.test(*self.arg)
  File "/Users/goldbaum/Documents/yt-hg/yt/fields/tests/test_fields.py", line 192, in test_add_smoothed_particle_field
    fn = base_ds.add_smoothed_particle_field(('io', 'particle_ones'))
  File "/Users/goldbaum/Documents/yt-hg/yt/data_objects/static_output.py", line 1015, in add_smoothed_particle_field
    raise ValueError("%s not in derived_field_list")
ValueError: %s not in derived_field_list

----------------------------------------------------------------------

```

Note that you can run just this test by doing


```
#!bash

$ nosetests yt.fields.tests.test_fields:test_add_smoothed_particle_field
```

In the root of the repository.

content.raw:
This won't work, you'll need to do something like:


```
#!python

raise ValueError("%s not in derived_field_list" % ((ptype, smoothing_length_name),))
```

Note how I'm using a tuple inside a tuple, this avoids an unpacking error.
content.html:
This won't work, you'll need to do something like:

raise ValueError("%s not in derived_field_list" % ((ptype, smoothing_length_name),))

Note how I'm using a tuple inside a tuple, this avoids an unpacking error.

content.raw: I think I need to make sure all of the (ptype, "particle_position"), (ptype, "particle_mass"), (ptype, "smoothing_length"), and (ptype, "density") fields are there. But I don't know how to do that.
content.html: I think I need to make sure all of the (ptype, "particle_position"), (ptype, "particle_mass"), (ptype, "smoothing_length"), and (ptype, "density") fields are there. But I don't know how to do that.

content.raw: If using `fake_particle_ds` is too hard (I have an open ticket to make this easier that I haven't gotten around to) you could decorate the test with `@requires_file`, which you can find in `yt/testing.py` and just load one of the public test SPH datasets on yt-project.org/data.

content.raw:
A practical solution would be to replace this line with:

```
assert_almost_equal(ret.sum(), 3824750.912653606)
```

That's perhaps not satisfying since it's not clear why it's exactly this number, but it should at least let the tests pass.

Another option would just be to not check if any particular value is returned and just verify that the smooth operation succeeded. We can always come back and add more stringent tests later.
content.html:

That's perhaps not satisfying since it's not clear why it's exactly this number, but it should at least let the tests pass.

Another option would just be to not check if any particular value is returned and just verify that the smooth operation succeeded. We can always come back and add more stringent tests later.

description: ``add_smoothed_particle_field`` is a wrapper of ``add_volume_weighted_smoothed_field`` which behaves similarly to ``add_deposited_particle_field``.
